 Thanks for responding, Unriggable. Let me address the points you raise....
 
 I'm going to disagree with the idea that mandatory locks would deter gun thefts. Locks are designed primarily as a safety measure to prevent an unauthorized person (such as a child) from firing a gun. They are not designed to deter a thief, who once he has stolen the gun can take as long as he wants to cut the lock. Therefore, I a disagree that mandatory locks would create a theft deterrent. 
 
 I also see no valid reason to force otherwise law abiding individuals to wait when purchasing a firearm. The claim that a waiting period deters crimes of sudden passion has always been a sham argument. The instant check system has been used for over a decade now, and there have been no reported increases in crimes committed with a gun purchased on the spur of the moment. Therefore, I see no justification for restricting access to a fundamental right when it serves no legitimate purpose.
 
 Now a permit/registration scheme is an interesting issue which comes with a few problems. The first problem would be the potential for massive passive resistance to a registration or permit scheme, like what we have seen in Canada. In my opinion it would be impossible to construct a permit or registration scheme that would cover the vast secondary (individual to individual "street" sales) market. The only way to enforce a permit or registration scheme would be to criminalize it and prosecute persons who get caught with a gun they did not register or did not obtain a permit for. This may be fine and good in the abstract, but in reality it would have no impact on fighting gun crime other than to make inadvertent criminals out of otherwise law-abiding gun owners.
 
 I say this because there will be a number of people who would be exempt from a permit or registration requirement. Convicted murderers, rapists, robbers, home burglars, child sexual offenders, or indeed any other convicted felon would be exempt. Also exempt would be convicted stalkers, persons found guilty of domestic violence, and persons previously involuntarily committed to a mental health institution for either past violence or the potential for future violence. We talk all the time about keeping guns out of these "wrong" hands, and these are the very people who would be immune from prosecution for refusing to submit to a mandatory permit or registration scheme. Here's why: 
 
 It is a crime for these persons to possess a firearm. If the state mandates that they announce their possession of a firearm through obtaining permits or registering firearms then it forces them to incriminate themselves in violation of their 5th. Amendment right. 
 
 This has been tried before. In 1968 Congress enacted a number of firearm restrictions under the title of the National Firearms Act. The NFA contained a mandatory firearm possession registration scheme; which required all persons to register possession of and be taxed on their possession of certain classes of firearms Congress determined were being used principally by persons engaged in unlawful activities. The registration scheme was enforced by two new criminal statutes: 26 U.S.C. § 5841 made it a crime for failure to register possession of a particular type of firearm, and 26 U.S.C. § 5851 made it a crime to possess an unregistered firearm. SCOTUS declared that prosecutions for a violation of these registration requirements was unconstitutional because registration compelled self-incrimination--See Haynes v. United States, 390 U.S. 85 (1968). Now we could try to avoid the constitutional challenge by calling it a "permit" scheme instead, but SCOTUS looks at the application of a law and not the title Congress gives it when deciding constitutionality, and a mandatory "permit" scheme is equivalent to a registration scheme in both its requirement of self-incrimination and its purpose of establishing a nationwide database.
